reasoning: The critique targets Sec. 2.4’s multiplicative independent-uniform toy model, which is an important support for the essay’s “fragility/rare mostly-great futures” intuition, but not the whole case (the essay also argues fussiness from population ethics, digital beings, and especially the Sec. 3 taxonomy of value functions). So centrality is moderate-high rather than decisive. The critique is fairly strong against the toy model as presented: independence/uniformity/multiplicativity are indeed substantive assumptions, and correlated ‘competence clusters’ or different moral aggregation rules could yield much more probability mass near high value, undermining the specific quantitative moral the authors draw from the toy model. However, it doesn’t fully overturn the broader claim that small moral mistakes can be high-impact (which the essay motivates with many non-toy considerations), and the essay could also reply that correlation may not be strongly positive or that some key dimensions remain weakly coupled, preserving tail fragility. Most claims in the critique are correct: the product-of-independent-uniforms setup is a pessimistic structure for upper-tail mass; correlation structure matters; many moral theories aren’t well-modeled by smooth multiplicative aggregation. Minor overreach: calling the model “maximally pessimistic” is a bit too strong (one can pick even more pessimistic factor distributions), but it’s directionally right. The critique is clear, focused on one core issue (model assumptions) with a few subpoints, and has little dead weight.
title: Correlated governance success and non-multiplicative ethics undermine the fragility model
